Hypotheses & Specific Predictions: 1.1.alt. FACFs are similar in tropical and temperate forests, but lower in boreal regions (CD-)
Related references: Gillman et al. (2015); Simova and Storch (2017)

Hypotheses & Specific Predictions: 1.2. Allocation to FACFs varies with latitude
Related references: Litton et al. (2007); DeLucia et al. (2007)

Hypotheses & Specific Predictions: 2.2. FACFs increase with precipitation but saturate or decrease at very high levels (CD+)
2.3. There is a postive interaction between temperature and precipitation (I+)
3.1. FACFs increases with PET, but saturates or decreases at high levels (CD+)
3.2. FACFs increase with vapour pressure deficit, but saturate or decrease at high levels (CD+)
3.3. FACFs increase linearly with solar radiation (L+)
4.1. FACFs decrease linearly with temperature seasonality (L-)
4.2. FACFs decrease linearly with  precipitation seasonality (L-)
4.3. FACFs increase linearly with growing season length (L+)
Related references: Malhi (2012); Michaletz et al. (2014); Chu et al. (2016)

Hypotheses & Specific Predictions: 4.4. Growing season length is a better predictor of FACFs than MAT
Related references: Michaletz et al. (2014); Chu et al. (2016)
